faq.title: Frequently asked questions
faq.subtitle: Everything you need to know about SecureScan
faq.q1: Is it safe to scan my site?
faq.a1: Yes, completely. We only analyze the public content of your website, just like any visitor would. We don't store any credentials found.
faq.q2: What types of API keys do you detect?
faq.a2: We detect over 40 types of keys: OpenAI, Stripe, AWS, Firebase, GitHub, Supabase, and many more. We also identify generic token and secret patterns.
faq.a3: The basic version is free to help the developer community. We offer premium features like scheduled scans and continuous monitoring.
faq.q4: What do I do if vulnerabilities are found?
faq.a4: We provide detailed instructions for each issue. Most importantly: immediately rotate exposed keys and move them to server environment variables.

openai.title: Exposed OpenAI API Key
openai.description: Exposed OpenAI API key. Anyone can make API calls and charges will go to your account. This can result in bills of thousands of dollars.
steps: Go IMMEDIATELY to platform.openai.com and revoke this key
Review usage history for unauthorized consumption
Create a new API key
Store the new key in server environment variables (never in frontend)
Create a backend endpoint that proxies requests to OpenAI

anthropic.title: Exposed Anthropic API Key
anthropic.description: Exposed Anthropic (Claude) API key. Allows unauthorized access to Claude API with charges to your account.
steps: Go to console.anthropic.com and revoke this key immediately
Generate a new API key
Store it only in server environment variables
Create a backend endpoint to handle requests to Claude

stripe_live.title: Exposed Stripe Secret Key (PRODUCTION)
stripe_live.description: URGENT: Stripe PRODUCTION secret key exposed. An attacker can make charges, refunds, view customer data and access all your payment information.
steps: URGENT: Rotate this key NOW in the Stripe Dashboard
This is a PRODUCTION key - review unauthorized transactions
Secret keys (sk_) should NEVER be in the frontend
Use only publishable keys (pk_) on the client side
Implement webhooks to verify payments securely

stripe_test.title: Exposed Stripe Secret Key (Test)
stripe_test.description: Stripe test mode secret key exposed. While it's test mode, it reveals your API structure and poor security practices.
steps: Rotate this key in the Stripe Dashboard
Move it to server environment variables
Never expose secret keys in client code

aws.title: Exposed AWS Access Key ID
aws.description: Exposed AWS Access Key ID. Combined with the secret key, it allows full access to your AWS services. Attackers can create resources, steal data or mine cryptocurrency at your expense.
steps: Deactivate this key IMMEDIATELY in the IAM console
Review CloudTrail for unauthorized usage
Create new credentials with minimum necessary permissions
Use IAM roles instead of access keys when possible
Never store AWS credentials in client code

google_firebase.title: Exposed Google/Firebase API Key
google_firebase.description: Exposed Google/Firebase API key. If not restricted, it can allow unauthorized use of Google APIs with charges to your account.
steps: Restrict this key in Google Cloud Console
Configure HTTP referrer restrictions (your domain)
Limit the key to only the APIs you need
Consider using Firebase App Check for better security

github_pat.title: Exposed GitHub Personal Token
github_pat.description: Exposed GitHub personal token. Allows access to your repositories, can create commits, delete repos and access private information.
steps: Revoke this token IMMEDIATELY in GitHub Settings
Review recent account activity
Create a new token with minimum necessary permissions
Use GitHub Apps or fine-grained tokens for better security
Never store tokens in repositories

bearer_token.title: Bearer Token Exposed in Network Request
bearer_token.description: A Bearer token is being sent from the frontend. This token is visible in browser dev tools and can be stolen.
steps: Move authentication to server-side (API routes)
Use httpOnly cookies instead of Authorization headers
Implement a backend proxy for authenticated requests
Never store or send tokens from client-side JavaScript

sensitive_param_high.title: Sensitive parameter in URL
sensitive_param_high.description: A sensitive value is being passed in URL parameters. URLs are saved in browser history, server logs and leaked via Referer headers.
steps: Never pass sensitive data in URL parameters
Use POST requests with data in the body
Move authentication to server-side
Use secure headers for authentication

sensitive_param_medium.title: Potentially sensitive parameter in URL
sensitive_param_medium.description: A potentially sensitive parameter was detected in the URL. It could be a public client key (acceptable) or a secret key (dangerous). Verify if this key should be public.
steps: Verify if it's a public client key (acceptable) or a secret key (dangerous)
Public keys for frontend APIs are safe to expose
Secret keys should NEVER be in URLs - use server requests
If it's a secret key, move the API call to your backend

content_security_policy.title: Missing Content-Security-Policy header
content_security_policy.description: Missing Content-Security-Policy (CSP) header. This header prevents XSS attacks by controlling which resources your page can load.
steps: Add the Content-Security-Policy header. Basic example: "default-src 'self'; script-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline'; style-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline'"

x_frame_options.title: Missing X-Frame-Options header
x_frame_options.description: Missing X-Frame-Options header. Without it, your site can be embedded in a malicious iframe for clickjacking attacks.
steps: Add the X-Frame-Options header with value "DENY" or "SAMEORIGIN" to prevent your site from being embedded in iframes from other domains.

x_content_type_options.title: Missing X-Content-Type-Options header
x_content_type_options.description: Missing X-Content-Type-Options header. Prevents the browser from "guessing" the content type, which can lead to vulnerabilities.
steps: Add the X-Content-Type-Options header with value "nosniff".

strict_transport_security.title: Missing HSTS header
strict_transport_security.description: Missing HSTS (Strict-Transport-Security) header. This header forces the browser to always use HTTPS, preventing man-in-the-middle attacks.
steps: Add the Strict-Transport-Security header with max-age of at least 31536000 (1 year). Example: "max-age=31536000; includeSubDomains"

x_xss_protection.title: Missing X-XSS-Protection header
x_xss_protection.description: Missing X-XSS-Protection header. While modern browsers use CSP, this header provides protection for older browsers.
steps: Add the X-XSS-Protection header with value "1; mode=block".

referrer_policy.title: Missing Referrer-Policy header
referrer_policy.description: Missing Referrer-Policy header. Controls how much referrer information is shared when navigating to other sites.
steps: Add the Referrer-Policy header with value "strict-origin-when-cross-origin" or more restrictive.

permissions_policy.title: Missing Permissions-Policy header
permissions_policy.description: Missing Permissions-Policy header. Controls which browser features your site can use (camera, microphone, geolocation, etc.).
steps: Add the Permissions-Policy header to restrict unnecessary features. Example: "camera=(), microphone=(), geolocation=()"

cors_wildcard.title: Critical CORS: Wildcard with Credentials
cors_wildcard.description: Your API allows credentials (cookies, auth headers) from any origin. This is EXTREMELY dangerous and allows session theft.
steps: NEVER use Access-Control-Allow-Origin: * with credentials
Specify exact domains when using credentials
Review your CORS configuration immediately

source_map.title: Exposed Source Maps
source_map.description: Publicly accessible source maps were found. Source maps reveal your original source code, including comments, variable names and business logic.
steps: Disable source map generation in production
In Next.js: productionBrowserSourceMaps: false in next.config.js
In Webpack: devtool: false for production
If you need source maps for debugging, use source-map-loader with authentication

env_file.title: Exposed .env File
env_file.description: The environment variables file is publicly accessible. It may contain secrets, API keys and database credentials.
steps: Block access to the file in server configuration
Add to .gitignore and remove from version control
Use environment variables instead of configuration files
Configure your hosting platform to deny access to sensitive files

git_exposed.title: Exposed Git Repository
git_exposed.description: The .git directory is publicly accessible. It can reveal the entire code history, including secrets that were deleted.
steps: Block access to the .git directory in server configuration
Review git history for exposed secrets
Consider using tools like git-secrets to prevent committing secrets

admin_panel.title: Accessible Admin Panel
admin_panel.description: A publicly accessible admin panel was detected. This can allow attackers to attempt accessing restricted areas.
steps: Restrict admin panel access by IP
Implement two-factor authentication
Use unpredictable URLs for the admin panel
Consider placing the admin panel on a separate subdomain

debug_endpoint.title: Accessible Debug Endpoint
debug_endpoint.description: A publicly accessible debug or phpinfo endpoint was detected. It reveals sensitive information about the server configuration.
steps: Remove or disable debug endpoints in production
Block access to phpinfo and similar files
Configure the server not to expose configuration information

database_exposed.title: Accessible Database
database_exposed.description: A publicly accessible database file or interface was detected. This can result in theft or total loss of data.
steps: Immediately block access to the database file
Move the database outside the public directory
Use strong authentication for database administration interfaces
Review data for possible unauthorized access

backup_exposed.title: Accessible Backup
backup_exposed.description: A publicly accessible backup file was detected. Backups often contain the entire source code and sensitive data.
steps: Immediately remove the backup from the public server
Store backups in secure locations outside the webroot
Configure the server to block access to .zip, .tar, .sql files

log_exposed.title: Accessible Log File
log_exposed.description: A publicly accessible log file was detected. Logs can contain sensitive information, errors and stack traces.
steps: Block access to log files
Store logs outside the public directory
Configure the server to deny access to .log files

config_file.title: Exposed Configuration File
config_file.description: A publicly accessible configuration file was detected. It may contain credentials and sensitive configuration.
steps: Block access to the file in server configuration
Move configuration files outside the public directory
Use environment variables instead of configuration files

http_insecure.title: Site using HTTP instead of HTTPS
http_insecure.description: Your site is accessible via HTTP, which transmits data unencrypted.
steps: Obtain an SSL certificate (free from Let's Encrypt)
Configure your server to redirect HTTP to HTTPS
Add the HSTS header to enforce HTTPS

mixed_content.title: Mixed Content Detected
mixed_content.description: Your HTTPS page loads resources over HTTP, which can be intercepted.
steps: Update all resource URLs to use HTTPS
Use protocol-relative URLs (//) where appropriate
Enable upgrade-insecure-requests in CSP
